Rising temperatures will affect global maize production, but the effect of increasing temperature variability is not well understood. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase dramatically. The resulting instability in global grain trade will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

Decades of research have revealed several mechanisms of resource partitioning, but the extent to which herbivores partition food-plant species is unknown because comprehensive species-level identification is difficult. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African herbivore species (six wild, one domestic). These species consumed over 700 plant species, and diet breadth was highly variable among individuals of the same species, indicating that both fine-grained and broad-scale dietary differences contribute to resource partitioning. We present the first worldwide survey of floating plastic debris in the open ocean, showing a clear accumulation of plastic in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, with comparable densities to those reported in the most polluted areas. stuffs: Potassium channels are gated by a large number of allosteric mechanisms. Coupling between the channel’s activation gate and its selectivity filter is one of the most intriguing and least understood. This allosteric coupling is essential for channel function and is the target of many drugs. We have identified a crucial residue in the activation gate’s signature sequence that controls this coupling. We have also discovered a deep inactivated conformation of the selectivity filter that is assumed by the channel upon the removal of intracellular K+ and characterized its structural features. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closing of the activation gate is not a prerequisite for the collapse of the selectivity filter. All of these findings are relevant to our understanding of the allosteric communication pathways in potassium channels.

следующее: The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is marked by rapid cooling of the Earth’s climate and is associated with a global layer of enriched iridium. stuffs: Lignocellulose, the most abundant plant material on Earth, is a recalcitrant polymer that is difficult to digest, even for plants themselves. []. The entanglement entropy is the natural generalization to quantum systems of the notion of entropy in classical statistical mechanics. It was a long-standing open problem to compute its dynamics after a sudden change of the Hamiltonian in interacting quantum systems. We solve this problem by using a combination of the Bethe ansatz and of the quasiparticle picture. Our result shows that the entanglement entropy behaves as a thermodynamic entropy in the long-time limit and that the dynamics of entanglement is a manifestation of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. Our approach is exact and applies to finite systems without taking the thermodynamic limit. Our result is exact and provides the dynamics of the entanglement entropy in interacting quantum systems. It is a fundamental building block for understanding time evolution in interacting quantum systems.

stuffs Repeated games are a prominent model in game theory for studying interactions between rational agents over an infinite horizon. A major obstacle for finding or even deciding upon the existence of rational (i.e., equilibrium) strategies in repeated games is the huge strategy space, which is exponentially larger than the state space. This obstacle is avoided in stochastic games and in Borel games, where the strategy space is the same as the state space. We show that a middle ground between repeated games and stochastic games exists: one can allow strategies that depend on the entire history of the game, as in repeated games, but restrict the payoff function so that it depends only on the asymptotic behavior of the play, as in Borel games. The resulting class of games has polynomial-size strategy spaces and admits equilibria.

The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario and to 80% under a high-emission scenario. Our results will be valuable for planning adaptation strategies to cope with future extremes in this vulnerable region.

eightieth anniversary of the Trinity nuclear test, we report the discovery of a new composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, in trinitite, the glass and other condensed phases formed by the intense heat and pressure of the Trinity explosion. The discovery of a quasicrystal in trinitite shows that quasicrystals can be formed by the impact of a meteorite, a nuclear explosion, or other extreme pressure–temperature events, as demonstrated by the synthesis of quasicrystals in laboratory experiments simulating meteorite impact. The discovery also demonstrates that quasicrystals can form in a wide range of alloy systems, in this case Si–Cu–Ca–Fe. The new Si–Cu–Ca–Fe quasicrystal system is related to the Al–Cu–Fe and Al–Cu–Ca quasicrystal systems found in the Khatyrka meteorite.

вдThe formation of the isocyclic ring of (bacterio)chlorophyll is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes, one of which is an [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, and the other is a diiron protein. Here, we show that the Ycf54 protein is a subunit of the O2-dependent cyclase in cyanobacteria and higher plants, and we identify a new cyclase subunit, BciE, in alphaproteobacterial phototrophs. Thus, three classes of the cyclase are now known, based on their requirement for additional subunits. The evolution of the cyclase is discussed. Knowledge of the structure of the cyclase, its mechanism, and its subunits is essential for understanding the remarkable adaptation of (bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis to oxygenic environments. This is a major unanswered question in photosynthesis.

wherea neuroinflammation is a prominent pathological feature of multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system (CNS), and a mouse model of multiple sclerosis, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), is used to understand the mechanisms of neuroinflammation. eighteen million people in California are currently under orders to cease nonessential water use as the state experiences record-setting drought. stuffs: A hallmark of many neurodegenerative diseases is the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins. Recent studies have highlighted the spreading of protein aggregates in major neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this spreading and whether it is related to disease pathology are poorly understood. We demonstrate that huntingtin aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the Drosophila brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate in other neurons, causing loss of vulnerable neurons. The release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, and aggregate spreading and endocytosis inhibition can prevent neuronal loss. These findings demonstrate that protein aggregates are actively released and internalized in vivo and that this process is pathogenic. Therefore, aggregate spreading may be an important therapeutic target.

вд Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. MTX inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H.

stuffs: We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

whereabout 130 million y ago, the first angiosperms appeared. From the very beginning angiosperms diversified rapidly and today they are the most diverse and successful plant group on Earth. However, the identity and ecology of these very early angiosperms is poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of the morphology and reproduction of Montsechia, an extremely early fossil angiosperm from Spain. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, an entirely aquatic plant genus. These data suggest that the most immediate ancestors of eudicots were aquatic and that aquatic habitats may have played an important role in the early evolution of angiosperms. The first angiosperms were diverse in habit and adapted to different ecological niches.

вдHuman parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen associated with a number of conditions such as fifth disease in children, arthritis and arthralgias in adults, and an important cause of viral arthritis in adults. B19V is thought to evolve exceptionally rapidly among DNA viruses. Here we present 10 B19V genomes from individuals who lived 0.5–6.9 thousand years ago. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and we find a substitution rate that is an order of magnitude lower than inferred previously. We are also able to date the recombination event that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study highlights the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics.

возле NMR-assisted crystallography is a rapidly emerging structural technique that combines the complementary information from X-ray crystallography, solid-state NMR spectroscopy, and first-principles computation. In particular, NMR chemical shifts provide a detailed map of atomic environments, including hydrogen bonding and hydrogen atom locations. Here, we report the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This species is a defining structure for the large class of enzymes that use pyridoxal 5′-phosphate as cofactor. The integrated structural information from NMR-assisted crystallography reveals the detailed chemical reactivity for this important intermediate, providing a rationale for the observed reaction regioselectivity and the lack of reactivity with benzimidazole, an isostere of the natural substrate indole. This study provides a roadmap for the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to enzymology.

wherea new treatment effective against Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is desperately needed, we tested the efficacy of the broad-acting antiviral remdesivir in the rhesus macaque model of MERS. Remdesivir reduced the severity of disease, virus replication, and damage to the lungs when administered either before or after animals were infected with MERS coronavirus. Our data support testing of remdesivir in a MERS clinical trial, which could have a beneficial effect in hospitalized patients. Since remdesivir also effectively inhibited the replication of the emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV in vitro, it may be considered as a potential treatment for the emerging pneumonia outbreak associated with this virus.

stuffs: The mutualism between the bobtail squid Euprymna scolopes and its light-producing bacterial symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a model system for studying host–microbe interactions. This mutualism is characterized by a daily rhythmic exchange of signals between the partners, which culminates in a daily light display by the squid. We show here that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host at night is a key signal that enables the symbionts to alter their metabolic activity and to produce light in the host organ. This result suggests that the strategic provision of glycans by their hosts may be an important mechanism by which animal hosts regulate the activities of their epithelial microbiota. Chitin is a major component of the exoskeleton of insects, which are a major source of food for squid in the wild. The squid’s provision of chitin to its microbiota may therefore also benefit the squid.

eighteenth-century philosopher Jeremy Bentham argued that the best way to encourage good behavior is to sustain people’s sense that others care about them. Yet in schools, the default response to misbehavior is to punish, which erodes students’ respect for teachers. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline—to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior—can be encouraged through brief, online training. This intervention also halved students’ suspension rates, a powerful predictor of long-term academic and life success. The study’s scalable intervention is a significant advance in the science of policy implementation. It offers a practical way to improve school discipline and promote positive outcomes for students and teachers.

stuffs: Alkylated DNA lesions interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We observed distinct pol II stalling profiles for the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions.

вдMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. MERS-CoV entry into cells requires two sequential cleavages of its spike (S) glycoproteins. The first cleavages occur while the virus is still in the virus-producing cell, and the second cleavages occur after the virus binds to its cell receptor. Here, we show that the first cleavages are required for efficient MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but are dispensable for infection into several other cell types. This cell-type specific requirement for the first S cleavages correlates with S conformations during cell entry. Thus, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

Here, we examine the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a year-long large-scale series of observational and experimental field studies. We estimate that the catering changes we studied could deliver annual CO2e savings of up to 25,900 t, equivalent to taking 6,500 cars off the road.

We found that each oncogene induces a unique surfaceome, but all induce common functional changes including increased nutrient uptake, decreased adhesion, and altered immune modulation. Our studies provide a systems-level view of how driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and glycoproteome.

stuffs: In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. We collect data from 1996 to 2018 on all three US states that implemented universal vote-by-mail in a staggered fashion across counties, allowing us to use a difference-in-differences design at the county level to estimate causal effects. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or modestly increase average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

stuffs: SARS-CoV-2, the cause of COVID-19, has rapidly spread across the globe, causing over 500,000 deaths worldwide. The structure provides a molecular basis for understanding the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may aid in the design of therapeutics targeting this rapidly spreading pathogen.

stuffs: Endothelial cells (ECs) are critical for vascularization and angiogenesis in development and tissue regeneration. The generation of functional ECs from nonvascular cells is a promising approach for clinical applications. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2), a member of the ETS family of transcription factors, can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs in a short period. The resultant ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel in vivo. Moreover, ETVECs improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic mouse model. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This method will be useful for generating autologous ECs for therapeutic applications.

stuffs Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important regulators of cell growth, cell differentiation, and cell survival. While much is known about the role of RTKs in cancer, less is known about their physiological functions. ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) are physiological ligands of the RTK anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk). Recently, a second RTK, leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk), was identified as a high-affinity receptor for augmentors. Here, we employ zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. Our experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation. These experiments have important implications for the understanding of the physiological roles of Alk and Ltk.

stuffs: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance (IR) and β-cell dysfunction. Here, using global stimulator of interferon genes (STING) knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Although STING−/− ameliorated IR and glucose intolerance, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). We found that STING was decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING was required for normal β-cell function and STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, STING regulated expression of transcription factor Pax6, which was associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis.

wherea selective mechanism ensures that only one copy of each of the eight genomic RNA segments is specifically packaged into each influenza A virion, thus ensuring proper viral genome delivery to the next host cell. The interaction takes place in regions of the RNA that are not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. stuffs: The use of natural repellents for pest control is an ecofriendly approach to maintaining ecological balance. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of natural repellents on arthropods remain largely unknown. In this study, we identified natural repellent-sensing receptors in the genome of the scorpion Mesobuthus martensii and in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, demonstrating that natural repellents are sensed by ancient arthropod chemosensory receptors. Our study provides insights into the molecular basis of arthropod responses to natural repellents, and should help in the development of strategies for pest control while conserving biodiversity. It also provides a rationale for the use of natural repellents in arthropod control. This study is significant for the fields of chemical ecology, pest control, and arthropod biology.

вдThe recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model. We characterize the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques and assess the effect of antiviral treatment on viral burden. Our results can be used to inform clinical trial design and treatment evaluation. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV is short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is only a few hours. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. Finally, we assess the effect of antiviral treatment on viral burden.

eighteen months of monitoring the physiology, metabolomics, and holobiont nutrient fluxes of the coral Stylophora pistillata under heat stress revealed the sequence of events leading to bleaching. The response of the coral holobiont to heat stress is characterized by a gradual breakdown of the symbiosis. This process is driven by the increasing metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which is compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids and the resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont. This shift in nutrient cycling promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. These processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host and bleaching. This study provides a unique mechanistic understanding of the processes leading to coral bleaching.

Here we find that the expression of ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which also enhanced expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). eighteen high-latitude Southern Hemisphere paleoclimate records show a unique, nearly synchronous acceleration in deglaciation ∼17.7 ka. Many changes are ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We document an unprecedented, ∼192-y series of massive, halogen-rich volcanic eruptions exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation from Mount Takahe, West Antarctica. Rather than a highly improbable coincidence, extensive volcanic fallout and climate impacts extend from the Antarctic Peninsula to the subtropics, similar to those associated with modern stratospheric ozone depletion over Antarctica. Collectively, these data and supporting model results strongly suggest that Mount Takahe eruptions triggered the abrupt shift to modern climate conditions in the Southern Hemisphere.

stuffs: The development of high-energy and safe energy storage devices is a key challenge for powering the sustainable society. stuffs: The Caenorhabditis elegans ALM mechanosensory neuron undergoes two morphologically similar forms of ectopic axon outgrowth in response to loss of sensory function: activity-dependent ectopic outgrowth (ADO) and dendrite-less regeneration (DLR). stuffs: Recombination is essential for proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis, but it is also a major cause of chromosomal rearrangements that underlie much of the variation in domesticated plants and animals. stuffs: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) is a critical cofactor for many enzymatic reactions and has also been shown to regulate gene expression. stuffs: Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. stuffs: Tomato fruit is a model system for studying ripening-associated volatile production, and the ripe fruit of many cultivated and wild tomato species is characterized by a distinct aroma. Here, we report the identification of a gene that is essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This is the first report of a monooxygenase enzyme involved in the formation of nitrogenous volatiles in fruit. The enzyme provides a target for metabolic engineering to improve tomato flavor quality.

вдThe loss of biodiversity and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. We use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that biodiversity is more important in maintaining ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. We found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the joint impacts of biodiversity loss and climate warming on ecosystem function.

Responsivity—how quickly a partner responds to you—is the primary driver of this effect. We show that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

stuffs: Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plant growth and development. Increasing evidence suggests that Si plays a role in plant resistance against a variety of pathogens and insects. eighteen of the Great Lakes coastal watersheds in the United States were sampled for nutrients during a 3-d period in August 2016. We found that smaller tributaries deliver relatively more nutrients per unit area than larger tributaries and that these nutrients are more bioavailable (dissolved inorganic nutrients). This suggests that small watersheds may have a greater potential to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. The higher bioavailability of nutrients from small watersheds also means that their impacts may extend beyond the immediate coastal zone. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. We speculate that such dynamics may have played a role in the prebiotic synthesis of biopolymers.

вд Prey capture is a critical biological process that has driven morphological innovation and diversification in animals. Studying how predatory specialization evolves can help us understand how food webs are structured, and how they have changed through time. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use specialized structures called tentilla to capture prey. These structures are highly variable, both within and among species, providing an excellent model system for studying the evolution of predatory specialization. Our results show that siphonophore specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types, suggesting that specialized feeding strategies have been important in the evolution of this group. These findings contribute to our understanding of how specialization has shaped food webs.

eighteen million people in Tanzania rely on forests for their livelihoods. There is growing evidence that these forests can improve people’s diets and nutritional status, but this has not been recognized in policy. We used a modeling approach that combined two-way fixed-effects regression analysis with covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting to assess the causal impact of deforestation on people’s dietary quality. We found that deforestation reduced fruit and vegetable consumption and vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. Our findings are important given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve diets and nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

We show that the recent trend of increasing vehicle capacity has resulted in higher subsoil compaction risks, with the chronic compaction of the entire subsoil profile in sight. We propose a redesign of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits, and we highlight the potential for a similar impact of prehistoric sauropods on subsoil compaction. Our findings call for a more sustainable approach to modern agriculture, where the higher capacity of farm machinery is accompanied by more stringent design that minimizes subsoil compaction. We suggest that the roaming of sauropods may have led to subsoil compaction as well.
